questions.text: A 4-year old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection is erythema infectiosum, also known as the fifth disease, which is a benign, self-limited exanthematous illness of childhood. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill. ( as in this child)

  • The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which occurs in 3 stages
    • The initial stage is erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance
    • The rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema in the 2nd stage
    • Central clearing of macular lesions occurs promptly, giving the rash a lacy, reticulated appearance
  • The rash tends to be more prominent on extensor surfaces, sparing the palms and soles.

 

B19 and HBoV (human bocavirus) are the only 2 parvoviruses known to be pathogenic in humans.

 

Other options:

Fever is characteristically high with Scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease (unlike in this patient)

The malar rash which is pathognomonic of SLE involves the cheek, bridge of nose and lower eyelids; Discoid lesions are rare in childhood; photosensitivity rash may be present

questions.text: An infant comes to a paediatrician and on examination there is a coarse systolic murmur in the mitral area with mild exercise intolerance. On echocardiogram there is a small muscular VSD. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch till 2 years then operate
Restrict physical activity and operate when weight is more than 15 kgs
Reassure about the benign nature of the disease and advice about dental hygiene

questions.solution:
Reassure the parents about the benign nature of the disease and the dental hygiene to be carefully maintained as they are at high risk for infective endocarditis.

  • In patients with small VSDs
    • Parents should be reassured of the benign nature of the lesion
    • They should be encouraged to live a normal life
    • No restrictions on physical activity
    • Surgical repair is not recommended
  • Small muscular VSDs are more likely to close (up to 80%) than membranous VSDs (up to 35%)
  • They only have a long-term risk for infective endocarditis so as a protection against infective endocarditis, the integrity of primary and permanent teeth should be carefully maintained.
  • The latest revision of the American Heart Association guidelines states: 
    • Antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended for dental visits or surgical procedures.
    • Patients can be monitored by a combination of clinical examination and non-invasive laboratory tests until the VSD has closed spontaneously.

questions.text: Refrigerated breast milk should be used within
questions.solution:
Refrigerated breast milk should be used within 24 hours.

  • Expressed breast milk can be frozen and stored for up to 3 months.
  • Breast milk should be thawed rapidly by holding under running tepid water and used completely within 24 hr after thawing.
  • Breast milk should never be microwaved.

Note: This is a controversial question. A difference of opinion among authors is noted regarding refrigeration of expressed breast milk. Nelson's (20th ed) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated and used within 48 hours and frozen for up to 6 months and used within 24 hours of thawing. However, Ghai(9th ed) mentions that breast milk can be refrigerated up to 24 hours and frozen at -20 degree C for about 3 months.

questions.text:
In what type of glomerular disease are the following findings seen?
Light microscopy: enlarged, pale glomeruli
Electron microscopy: epithelial humps
questions.solution:
The findings mentioned are characteristic of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Findings in PSGN:

  • Light microscopy: enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and increase in mesangial matrix. PMN infiltration in early stages.
  • Immunofluorescence: “lumpy-bumpy” deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the GBM and in the mesangium.
  • Electron microscopy:  electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of the glomerular basement membrane.

Other options:

Idiopathic rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis:

  • Light microscopy -Crescents develop in several forms of glomerulonephritis (are a characteristic response to deposition of fibrin in Bowman’s space)
  • Electron microscopy – no deposits

Focal segmental glomerulonephritis:

  • Light microscopy - Focal sclerotic lesions
  • Electron microscopy - Foot process fusion

Minimal change disease:

  • Light microscopy – normal
  • Electron microscopy - Foot process fusion

questions.text: Which one of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?
questions.solution:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure

After birth:

  • The pulmonary vascular resistance decreases
  • The aortic pressure increases due to increased venous return from the lungs.
  • The blood flow through the ductus reverses
  • Highly oxygenated blood flows from the aorta through the ductus which creates a stimulus for the muscular spasm and subsequent closure.
  • Thus, in a full-term neonate, oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.
  • When the Po2 of the blood passing through the ductus reaches about 50 mm Hg, the ductal wall begins to constrict.
  • The effects of oxygen on ductal smooth muscle may be direct or mediated by its effects on prostaglandin synthesis.
  • Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed.

questions.text: Gower's manoeuvre is classically seen in:
questions.solution:
• Waddling gait, Gower sign, and calf muscle pseudo hypertrophy are classical signs seen around 3-4 years of age in children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: A male infant with a weak urinary stream has the VCUG picture as shown below. All statements about this condition is true EXCEPT:

choices.text: There is a palpably distended bladder and the urinary stream is weak
A Foley (balloon) catheter should not be used
Favorable prognostic factor is a serum creatinine level >1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression

questions.solution:
• The Voiding cystourethrogram in this infant shows posterior urethral valves. Note the dilation of the prostatic urethra and the transverse linear filling defect corresponding to the valves.
  • A serum creatinine level >1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression in posterior urethral valves is an unfavorable prognostic factor ( NOT favorable factor).
  • A serum creatinine level <0.8-1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression is considered favorable.

Other options: are all true

  • In the male neonate, posterior urethral valves are suspected when there is a palpably distended bladder and the urinary stream is weak.
  • A Foley (balloon) catheter should not be used, because the balloon can cause severe bladder spasm, which can produce severe ureteral obstruction.
  • 15% of boys with posterior urethral valves have unilateral reflux into a nonfunctioning dysplastic kidney, termed the VURD syndrome (valves, unilateral reflux, dysplasia).

questions.text: All of the following are components of Jones criteria for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever, except ______.
questions.solution:
Prolonged PR interval is a component of Jones criteria, not shortened PR interval

Jones criteria for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever includes:

Major criteria Minor criteria Supporting evidence of antecedent GAS (Group A Streptococci) infection
  • Carditis
  • Polyarthritis
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Chorea

Clinical

  • Arthralgia
  • Fever

Laboratory:

  • Elevated acute phase reactants
  • ESR
  • C reactive protein
  • Prolonged PR interval
  • Positive throat culture or rapid streptococcal antigen test
  • Elevated or increasing streptococcal antibody titer

Diagnosis can be established if a person fulfils 2 major OR 1 major and 2 minor criteria, AND has evidence of preceding GAS infection.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called
questions.solution:
• Object permanence is a major developmental milestone, attained at the age of 8-9 months. It is the understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen.
  • Object permanence is firmly established by 18 months of age; toddlers anticipate where an object will end up, even though the object was not visible while it was being moved.

 Other options:

  • Separation anxiety – the child becomes clingy and cries anxiously at bedtime or when separated from the parents. Separation anxiety begins about 10 mo of age and tapers off by 18 mo.
  • Transitional object – it may be a blanket or a stuffed toy which functions as a symbol of the absent parent.
  • Egocentric symbolic play seen at 12 months - Make-believe (symbolic) play centers on the child’s own body (pretending to drink from an empty cup) ; Symbolic transformations in play are no longer tied to the toddler’s own body by 18 months, so that a doll can be “fed” from an empty plate.

questions.text: Fanconi anemia can lead to:
questions.solution:
• Fanconi anemia (FA) is primarily inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
  • In FA marrow failure usually ensues in the 1st decade of life.
  • Thrombocytopenia and red blood cell macrocytosis often appears initially, with subsequent onset of granulocytopenia and then anemia.
  • Severe aplasia develops in most cases
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only curative therapy for the hematologic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 2 week old baby suspected to have congenital adrenal hyperplasia; the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (21-hydroxylase deficiency) is most reliably established by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone.
  • Measurements are taken before and 30 or 60 min after an intravenous bolus of 0.125-0.25 mg of cosyntropin (ACTH 1-24).
  • Nomograms exist that readily distinguish normal and patients with non-classic and classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: Not a component of Hutchinson’s triad in congenital syphilis
questions.solution:
Hutchinson’s triad is a triad of stigmata seen characteristically in congenital syphilis.

Components are:

  • Hutchinson teeth
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Sensorineural deafness (NOT conductive deafness)

questions.text: Lisch nodules is seen in:
questions.solution:
Lisch nodules, are commonly seen in patients with neurofibromatosis (NF 1). Lisch nodules represent melanocytic hamartomas of the iris.

In NF1 two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules
  • Two or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoid dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

Other options:

  • In Tuberous sclerosis the cardinal features are – skin manifestations (hypopigmented, ash leaf shaped macules, angiofibromas and adenoma sebaceum), convulsion and mental retardation.
  • In Sturge weber syndrome the characteristic feature is the facial port wine stain (usually in the distribution of the first branch of the trigeminal nerve but not limited to it), leptomeningeal angioma and glaucoma.
  • In Wilson disease, the distinctive corneal sign is the Kayser-Fleischer ring, a golden-brown ring in the peripheral cornea resulting from changes in Descemet’s membrane.

questions.text: All are seen in Tetralogy of Fallots except:
questions.solution:
ASD is not seen in TOF

  • TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).
  • The primary defect gives rise to the 4 anatomical components of TOF which are:
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD) ( NOT ASD)
  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow - Pulmonic stenosis (PS)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • Overriding (or dextroposition) of the aorta
  • Obstruction to pulmonary arterial blood flow is usually at both the right ventricular infundibulum (subpulmonic area) and the pulmonary valve.
  • The degree of pulmonary outflow obstruction determines the degree of the patient’s cyanosis and the age of first presentation.

questions.text: A male is said to have delayed puberty if it is not attained by:

• Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive of delayed puberty.

  • Constitutional delay in growth and puberty is the commonest cause of delayed puberty in boys

questions.text: Parachute reflex disappear at:
questions.solution:
• The Parachute reflex is a primitive reflex that occurs at 7-8 months of age and it is fully developed by 10-11 months of the postnatal period.
  • It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.
  • This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

Rooting 32 wk gestation 36 wk gestation Less prominent after 1 mo postnatal
Moro 28-32 wk gestation 37 wk gestation 5-6 mo postnatal
Tonic neck 35 wk gestation 1 mo postnatal 6-7 mo postnatal

questions.text: The most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism is

questions.text: A 5 day old infant seen with this transient rash. These papular lesions on an erythematous base on microscopic examination will reveal:
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is that of Erythema toxicum which are eosinophil laden sterile lesions.

  • They are papular lesions on an erythematous base seen in many babies
  • They are distributed over the trunk and face predominantly
  • Seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week
  • They resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment

Neutrophils are seen in lesions of Pustular Melanosis which is another benign transient skin finding in newborns.

questions.text:
A child with CAH having cortisol deficiency is treated with glucocorticoids. How should the dose of glucocorticoids be altered during an inter-current infection?

CAH - Congenital Adrenal hyperplasia

choices.text: Dose should be tapered and stopped
Dose should be doubled or tripled
Glucocorticoids should be withdrawn until the infection resolves

questions.solution:
Cortisol deficiency in CAH is treated with glucocorticoids.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as an infection or surgery. This is because, during periods of stress, the requirement for cortisol is higher.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome?

choices.text: Constitutes of a single seizure type
Good prognosis and adequate controlled epilepsy
EEG showing slow (<3Hz) spike and wave discharge

questions.solution:
Lennox–Gastaut syndrome is associated with 1-2 Hz spike and slow-wave discharges.

  • Typically starts between the ages of 2 and 10 years
  • Consists of a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizure types (that as a rule includes atypical absence seizures, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures) and specific EEG abnormalities.
  • Most are left with long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.
  • Lennox–Gastaut syndrome has a poor prognosis

 

Note: The United States FDA, in 2018, approved the usage of cannabidiol oral solution for the treatment of seizures associated with Lennox–Gastaut syndrome and Dravet syndrome, in patients two years or older.

questions.text: A young boy presented with a history of a genetic disorder. On further enquiry, his father and grandmother had the same disease as well. Prior to his birth, the doctor had counseled the father that there is a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to his offspring irrespective of sex.  Which of the following diseases is an example of this inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominance is the inheritance pattern seen in his question due to three-generation of affected family members with a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to the next generation irrespective of sex. Tuberous sclerosis is an example of an autosomal dominant (AD) disorder.

Note:

  • All Ehlers–Danlos syndrome types are autosomal dominant, except types V, VI, and VII.
  • All types of osteogenesis imperfecta are autosomal dominant, except types II, III, and VII.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm, smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderate hypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. This condition can be associated with all of the following except  ___________.
questions.solution:
Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor.

Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. 

Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilms tumor.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: A young girl was referred to the paediatrician with stage IV breast development and growth acceleration seen at the age of 5 years. Her estradiol concentrations were elevated. The sagittal MRI of the brain is as shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
A pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle as shown in the MRI, with elevated levels of estrogen is suggestive of a Hypothalamic Hamartoma, which is the most common brain lesion causing central precocious puberty and is treated with GnRH agonists. 

Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma-

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice of tumour-induced Central precocious puberty                                                                                                  
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.


Long-acting formulations of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are the preparations of choice for the treatment of central precocious puberty as they maintain fairly constant serum concentrations of the drug for weeks or months.

questions.text: Blueberry muffin rash is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Blueberry muffin rash refers to purple papulonodular lesions which represent dermal erythropoiesis. It is seen in the following:-

  • Viral infections such as Rubella, CMV and parvovirus
  • Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and AML
  • Rh haemolytic disease
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis

questions.text: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she is noted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes with epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most common lesion expected in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

 Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere)

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum
  • Protruding tongue
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes

Note:

  • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign).
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). 
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life.
  • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia.
  • The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM).
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome

Image: Brushfield's spots

World Down Syndrome Day is observed annually on March 21, 21st day of 3rd month, signifies trisomy 21. The theme for the year 2023 is "With Us Not For Us", signifying a human rights-based approach where people with disabilities have the right to be treated fairly & have the same opportunities as everyone else, working With others to improve their lives.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and rashes for the past 1 week after extensive workup gets diagnosed as Juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following findings is not consistent with this baby’s diagnosis?

choices.text: The genetic study may reveal NF-1 mutation
The presence of Philadelphia chromosome on FISH
The bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern with <20% blasts.
The peripheral smear reveals nucleated RBCs

questions.solution:
Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome.

Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients with JMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations.

Patients with this disease do not have the Philadelphia chromosome (the Philadelphia chromosome is characteristic of CML). The peripheral blood smear shows an elevated leukocyte count with increased monocytes, thrombocytopenia, and anemia with the presence of erythroblasts. Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20% of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for this type of leukemia.

JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneous resolution.

questions.text: Marked accumulation of cholesterol and lipids in the adrenal cortex and gonads associated with severe impairment of all steroidogenesis is seen in
questions.solution:
• Lipoid adrenal hyperplasia is usually caused by mutations in the gene for steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR), a mitochondrial protein.
  • Patients with this disorder exhibit marked accumulation of cholesterol and lipids in the adrenal cortex and gonads, associated with severe impairment of ALL steroidogenesis.

questions.text: During a telemedicine consultation, you come across a case of a 9-year-old child with a previously diagnosed autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome known as tuberous sclerosis. Which one of the following is not seen in it?
questions.solution:
Ependymomas are not seen in tuberous sclerosis. Neurocutaneous syndromes like tuberous sclerosis are a group of disorders with abnormalities in both the integumentary system and the CNS (defect of primitive ectoderm). They include the following:

  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Tuberous sclerosis
  • Sturge–Weber syndrome
  • von Hippel–Lindau disease
  • Ataxia telangiectasia

Tuberous sclerosis is caused due to mutation of genes coding for hamartin (chromosome 9) and tuberin (chromosome 16), which leads to the formation of hamartomas.

Clinical features:

  • CNS
    • CNS involvement is the hallmark of tuberous sclerosis.
    • Glioneuronal hamartomas (cortical tubers).
    • Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles, where they undergo calcification.
    • Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs) are the characteristic brain tumours. These benign, slow-growing tumours arise in the periventricular area.
    • White matter lesions are common and include nodules, cysts, and areas of gliosis and hypomyelination.
  • Skin
    • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Periungual fibroma
    • Shagreen patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
  • Others
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma

 

Note:
Ependymomas are WHO grade II (high-grade) tumours that are seen in neurofibromatosis-2, and not in tuberous sclerosis. However, subependymomas are benign, WHO grade I (low-grade) tumours, which are sometimes associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with dark coloured urine. Urinalysis was notable for macroscopic hematuria and heavy proteinuria. His father is a known case of Alport syndrome. What defect is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

questions.text: A preterm, extremely low birth weight baby, delivered by emergency caesarian section was admitted to the NICU and treated for respiratory distress syndrome. She responded to treatment and was discharged. At 6 months of age, she is still having recurrent respiratory distress and requires supplemental oxygen at home. The baby was diagnosed with bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Which of the following does not cause this clinical complication?
questions.solution:
Inhalation of nitrous oxide (N2O) is not associated with bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD). Inhaled NO is a pulmonary vasodilator approved for the treatment of hypoxic respiratory failure in term and near-term infants with pulmonary hypertension. It may have a role in preventing BPD.

BPD is a pathologic process leading to clinical features of chronic lung disease that originates in the neonatal period and is defined by an oxygen requirement for 28 days postnatally. Inflammatory injury to the developing lungs due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity resulting from prolonged mechanical ventilation is the key factor driving the pathogenesis of BPD. Together with other antenatal and postnatal factors, it results in aberrant tissue repair, dysregulated vascular and arrested alveolar development, which is the basis of the pathology seen in BPD.
